Twin ealvta arc generally smaller than average calvca of tin- breed, hut when utrong and vigoroun attain us great »ize ax the average. , i CARE OF CALVES AT Bin III III cold weather if a cow will not own her calf and lick it, the cull' nIiouIiI h« dried by rubbing with *traw or cloilm and hy eover- Ing it with 11 blanket which bai been ht-nted. (,'are should be ihIm'ii to avoid eold draftM and to keep hoth the calf and its mother comfortable. It i> itnportiint that the cult' secure MtM of the 1 i i — ■ i milk or colostrum, which is very hcncficial in promoting the proper action of the digestive tract. In cim the cow'a Brat milk in found to he bloody, clotted or otberwiae unlit lor the calf, the milk from (mother cow juit fresh inny he given, or if mich is not avail - able wmic laxative drug miiy he added to milk and given the calf instead of allowing it to nume its dam. For thin purpose one-half ounce to 1 ounce of castor oil or one-half to 1 ounce of Bpaotn ..nits may be given hy mixing with one-half to 1 pint of warm milk and pouring it into the calf* mouth from a bottle. Twelve to twenty-four hour* is usually a wufticicut length ■>!' time for a calf to remain with its dam. Mtrong, vigorouit calve* li(M|ii,.nt|y secure ho much milk thru minting during the lir.st day, especially when their damn are heavy milker*, that ucouring re - sults. For this reason it is often oeceaaary to *cparate ituch calven from their dimis when they are about twelve hours old, or as noon iis they have received one good till of the lirst milk. It ia much easier to teach calve* to drink if Ncparatcd from their dam* at an early age than when they arc allowed to nurse for several days. TEACH THE CALF TO DRINK AT AN EARLY AGE Must calveM cannot be readily taught to drink until they be - come quite hiiungry. The easiest method to follow is to offer no milk to the ealf until it ha* remained tteparate from its dam for 12 to 24 hours. Then a small quantity of the mother's milk at ;is nearly body temperature us poacible may be offered. It is usually necessary to encourage the ealf to drink and to me a considerable amount of patience and perseverance. To get the calf started drink - ing, the attendant may moisten his fingeri* with milk and allow the calf to suck them. The hand may then be slowly lowered into the milk until the calf* none touches the milk. After a few minutes the fingers may be removed from the calf's mouth. It is not r good plan to forec the calf's head into the pail and to hold it there

Raining Dairy Calves 5 as the calf may choke. With a little patience on the part <>f the feeder, many <hI\cn learn to drink well at thu firm or » ml feed inf. FEEDING WHOLE MILK Whole milk i* the natural feed for young calves and eon - tuiiiH all the element* iii-ci-N»ary for their maintenance and growth. In meeeaaful calf rawing it is abnolutely neceiwary to feed whole milk until nidi time u» the calf in able to obtain it* nouriiihmcnt from other feed*. TIuh mean* that tiNiially whole milk muitt be I'nl for at iciiHt throe, week*, hh at that age calves will cat small quantities of hay and grain. It in generally beat to give t'or the lirst three or four day*. the calf milk from it* own dam After that time the mixed herd milk may be fed. The amount of milk fed xliniild In- in moat I'tiM'N in proportion to the weight of tlie calf, One. pound of whole milk per day to each 10 pounds live weifht of the calf Niifllei(>nt for calve* of the i- Jeney and Guernsey breed*. while to Ayrshire ami HoUtcin calvet* 1 pound of milk to each H pounds of live weight may be fed. 16 Nebraska Extennwn Service out in circular patehc* ami thick scaly crust* form on the •kin. Some itching is often present. The i-riistK should be remove. I by washing with soap ami water and the area painted with tincture of iodine, sulphur oint - ment or acetic acid. The painting should be repeated every two or three day* ax long as necessary. To eradicate the disease the stable must be thoroly disinfected and whitewashed to destroy the spores of the disease which become scattered in mangers and ubout the stalls. Care must lie exercised in handling ealve* af - fected with the disease, as it is communicable to man. Mange and Itch — These ailments more commonly aflWt m« - ture eattle but may affect calvex. They are cauxed by Minall mites which tpread rapidly from one animal to another. The treatment pon«igt8 in thoro watthing or dipping in a disinfectant solution and disinfection of the quarters as tueiitiond in the discussion of lice.
